article.description: Antawn Jamison scored 24 points as the Golden State Warriors won their second straight home game under new coach Winters, beating Detroit 101-88 Wednesday night.
article.headline: Jamison says Warriors' attitude improved after switch
article.linkText: Warriors feel positive vibe after beating Pistons
article.story:
OAKLAND, Calif. (AP) -- Brian Winters insists he hasn't changed much since taking over for Dave Cowens. His players say the difference is enormous. Antawn Jamison scored 24 points as the Golden State Warriors won their second straight home game under new coach Winters, beating Detroit 101-88 Wednesday night. Golden State, 2-1 since Cowens was fired Saturday, ran away from Detroit with a 21-8 surge that began late in the third quarter. By the final minutes of a comfortable victory, the Warriors actually appeared to be having fun -- no small achievement for a team with seven straight losing seasons. "A lot has changed," Jamison said. "The things that we're trying to do, the places we're trying to get certain people ... it's a new attitude, and you could see it out there." During his five days in charge, Winters has re-emphasized team defense, urged the Warriors to run the court more freely, and established a fairly firm nine-man playing rotation. Those little things have made a big difference for the Warriors, who got just their third win in 12 games after opening the season 7-7. "We did a lot of good things," Winters said. "I'm seeing progress. I like the way we're responding. Ask me after 20 games ... but so far, so good." Jason Richardson, a Michigan native well aware the game was televised back home, had three rim-rattling dunks among his 18 points. He said he turned off his cell phone earlier in the week because of the avalanche of phone calls from friends and relatives who couldn't wait to see the game. Richardson and Chris Mills hit big baskets during the decisive run as Golden State beat Detroit for just the second time in the clubs' last 11 meetings. Jerry Stackhouse had 21 points on 9-of-23 shooting for the Pistons, who have lost the first three games of a five-game West Coast trip. Detroit, which shot 42 percent and looked sluggish in its third game in four nights, has lost four straight on the road overall. While the Warriors found their rhythm, the Pistons have lost theirs. "We have to get back to where we were," Stackhouse said. "We are out of sync. This type of thing is going to happen, and it's easy to go in different directions. We just need to continue to pick each other up. We'll be all right. We just need to weather the storm." Larry Hughes had 16 points for the Warriors, who matched Detroit's physical style while also outrunning the Pistons on fast breaks. Golden State led throughout the second half and got a rare standing ovation from the Arena crowd in the final seconds. In a matchup of two of the NBA's top rebounding forwards, Danny Fortson had eight points and 18 rebounds for Golden State, while Ben Wallace had 10 points and 15 rebounds. Detroit, which fell out of first place in the Central Division with Tuesday night's loss at Sacramento, didn't have the energy to match the Warriors' scoring. Clifford Robinson had five points, but he went 5-of-17 from the field. "I was more concerned about our defensive disposition," Detroit coach Rick Carlisle said. "We need to get back where we were during the first month of the season. We have slipped, and we need to make up that ground. They had us on our heels all night." Starting center Erick Dampier had five points and blocked five shots for the Warriors before leaving in the third quarter with a strained left hamstring. Dampier will be re-evaluated Thursday, but he didn't think the injury was serious.

Game notes
Golden State outrebounded Detroit 46-35. The Warriors have outrebounded their opponents in 22 of 26 games this season. ... Robinson and Golden State rookie Troy Murphy got technical fouls for a shouting match in the fourth quarter. ... One thing hasn't changed since Winters took over: $24 million center Marc Jackson hasn't left the Warriors' bench in eight straight games. ... Wallace, a 43 percent free throw shooter, airballed a foul shot for the second straight night.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
